title: Dems' key witness testifies in impeachment probe
text:
What Democrats cited as 'corroborating evidence' was brushed off as hollow testimony by Republicans, after a senior U.S. diplomat was grilled behind closed doors by lawmakers over the weekend on President Trump's dealings with Ukraine.

Two sources told Reuters Philip Reeker, the acting assistant secretary of state for European and Eurasian affairs, testified on Capitol Hill that he did not know whether Trump withheld aid to Ukraine to force an investigation into political rival Joe Biden and his son Hunter.

Reeker said he knew the aid had been withheld, but not why, the sources said.

But Democrats said Reeker corroborated evidence gathered in their impeachment probe against President Trump, which was sparked by a whistleblower's complaint about a July phone call Trump had with Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelensky.

Democrats offered no details of the testimony, however, and it was not clear what Reeker may have corroborated.

Reeker's testimony came after acting U.S. ambassador to Ukraine William Taylor Jr. testified that Trump made aid to Ukraine contingent on Zelensky launching an investigation into the Bidens' dealings in Ukraine.

Appearing on CBS's "Face the Nation" Sunday, Vice President Mike Pence balked when asked directly if he had heard that Trump made such a deal.

(SOUNDBITE) (English) CBS 'FACE THE NATION' HOST MARGARET BRENNAN, SAYING:

"I haven't gotten a clear answer from you on that though, sir... Are you saying you did not ever hear of such a deal? Is that what I understand you're describing?"

(SOUNDBITE) (English) U.S. VICE PRESIDENT MIKE PENCE, SAYING:

"I'm telling you that all of my interactions with the president, all of my conversations with President Zelensky, were entirely focused on issues of importance to the American people... and supporting Ukraine in a way that would restore its territorial integrity and stand by Ukraine for its sovereignty."

Republican Representative Mark Meadows told reporters Reeker offered no "incriminating" evidence following his testimony.

(SOUNDBITE) (English) REPUBLICAN REPRESENTATIVE MARK MEADOWS SAYING:

"The testimony was, in broad terms, a good day for the president."

This week, Democrats leading the impeachment inquiry expect to hear from several more top officials, including Alexander Vindman, the White House National Security Council's top Ukraine expert.
